The boy began lessons with an old Japanese judo master， and he was doing well. But he couldn&#39;t understand why， after three months of training，the master had taught him only one move.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;Sir，&quot; the boy finally said， &quot;shouldn&#39;t I be learning more moves?&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&ldquo;This the only move you know， but this is the only move you&#39;ll ever need to know，&quot; the master replied.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Not quite understanding， but believing in his teacher， the boy kept training.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Several months later， the master took the boy to his first tournament(锦标赛).</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Surprising himself， the boy easily won his first two matches. The third match</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	proved to be more difficult， but after some time， his opponent became impatient and charged; the boy skillfully used his one move to win the match. Still amazed by his success， the boy was now in the finals.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	This time， his opponent was bigger， stronger， and more experienced. For a while，the boy appeared to be overmatched. Concerned that &nbsp;the boy might get hurt , the &nbsp;referee alled a &nbsp;time-out ,He was about to stop the match when the judomaster intervened.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;No，&quot; the judo master insisted，&quot;Let him continue.&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Soon after the match resumed， his opponent made a critical mistake: he dropped his guard. Instantly， the boy used his move to pin him. The boy had won the match and the tournament. He was the champion.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	On the way home， the boy and his judo master reviewed every move in each and every match. Then the boy summoned the courage to ask what was really on his mind.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;Sir， how did I win the tour&tau;lament with only one move?&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;You won for two. reasons，&quot; the master answered.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;First， you&#39;ve almost mastered one of the most difficult throws in all of judo.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Second， the only known defense for that move is for your opponent to grab your left arm&rdquo;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	31．Why did the boy want to learn judo?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. He wanted to get over the accident.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. He wanted to make up for his disability.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. He wanted to exercise his right arm.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D &nbsp;.The reason was not mentioned in the passage</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	32.When a referee calls a &quot;time-out&rdquo;__________</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. the time has run out</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. the game stops for a short time</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. either side can claim victory</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. the game ends in a tie</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	33. Why did the master insist on continuing the match?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. He didn&#39;t want to give the opponent an advantage.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. The boy was confident of winning.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. He had confidence in the boy&#39;s skill.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. All he cared about was winning the final.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	34.What probably caused the defeat of the boy&#39;s opponent in the final?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. Over-confidence. B .Impatience.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C.Inexperience. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; D. Exhaustion.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	35. Why did the master teach the boy only that one move?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. The boy could not do other moves with only one arm.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. It was the only move the master knew well.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. It was the move his opponent would not be good at.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. His opponent would be helpless once he made that move.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	36. What does the passage mainly tell us？</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. One can turn a weakness into an advantage.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. Choose the best one and mark the corresponding letter with a single bar across the square brackets on your machine-scoring ANSWER SHEET.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Passage One</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A 10-year-old boy decided to study judo(柔道) despite the fact that he had lost his left arm in a terrible car accident. The boy began lessons with an old Japanese judo master， and he was doing well. But he couldn&#39;t understand why， after three months of training，the master had taught him only one move.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;Sir，&quot; the boy finally said， &quot;shouldn&#39;t I be learning more moves?&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&ldquo;This the only move you know， but this is the only move you&#39;ll ever need to know，&quot; the master replied.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Not quite understanding， but believing in his teacher， the boy kept training.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Several months later， the master took the boy to his first tournament(锦标赛).</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Surprising himself， the boy easily won his first two matches. The third match</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	proved to be more difficult， but after some time， his opponent became impatient and charged; the boy skillfully used his one move to win the match. Still amazed by his success， the boy was now in the finals.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	This time， his opponent was bigger， stronger， and more experienced. For a while，the boy appeared to be overmatched. Concerned that &nbsp;the boy might get hurt , the &nbsp;referee alled a &nbsp;time-out ,He was about to stop the match when the judomaster intervened.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;No，&quot; the judo master insisted，&quot;Let him continue.&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Soon after the match resumed， his opponent made a critical mistake: he dropped his guard. Instantly， the boy used his move to pin him. The boy had won the match and the tournament. He was the champion.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	On the way home， the boy and his judo master reviewed every move in each and every match. Then the boy summoned the courage to ask what was really on his mind.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;Sir， how did I win the tour&tau;lament with only one move?&quot;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;You won for two. reasons，&quot; the master answered.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&quot;First， you&#39;ve almost mastered one of the most difficult throws in all of judo.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Second， the only known defense for that move is for your opponent to grab your left arm&rdquo;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	31．Why did the boy want to learn judo?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. He wanted to get over the accident.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. He wanted to make up for his disability.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. He wanted to exercise his right arm.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D &nbsp;.The reason was not mentioned in the passage</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	32.When a referee calls a &quot;time-out&rdquo;__________</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. the time has run out</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. the game stops for a short time</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. either side can claim victory</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. the game ends in a tie</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	33. Why did the master insist on continuing the match?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. He didn&#39;t want to give the opponent an advantage.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. The boy was confident of winning.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. He had confidence in the boy&#39;s skill.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. All he cared about was winning the final.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	34.What probably caused the defeat of the boy&#39;s opponent in the final?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. Over-confidence. B .Impatience.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C.Inexperience. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; D. Exhaustion.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	35. Why did the master teach the boy only that one move?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. The boy could not do other moves with only one arm.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. His opponent would be helpless once he made that move.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	36. What does the passage mainly tell us？</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. One can turn a weakness into an advantage.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. It is very difficult to have a good teacher.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C &nbsp; Even a disabled person can win a match.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. &nbsp;Practice makes perfect.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	PassageTwo</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	My five-year-old daughter knew exactly what she wanted for Christmas of 1977， and told me so. Yes， she still would like the pink-and-green plastic umbrella， books， long nightgown， slippers-fine. But really， there was only one thing that mattered: a Barbie Townhouse， with all the accessories.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	This was a surprise. Rebecca was not a Barbie girl， preferred stuffed animals to dolls， and wasn&#39;t drawn to play in a structured environment. Always a make-up-the-rules， design-my-own-world， do-it-my-way kid. Maybe， I thought， the point wasn&#39;t Barbie but the house， which she could claim，for herself， since we&rsquo;d &nbsp;already moved five times during her brief life.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Next day， I stopped at the mall. The huge Barbie Townhouse box was there: &quot;3 Floors of High-Styled Fun! Elevator Can Stop on All Floors!&quot; Some Assembly Required.Uh-oh. My track record for assembling things was miserable. Brooklyn-born， I was raised in apartment buildings in a family that didn&#39;t build things. A few years earlier，I &#39;d spent one week assernbling a six-foot-tall jungle gym from a kit containing so many parts. I spent the first four hours sorting and the last two hours trying to figure out why there were so many pieces. The day after I finished building it， as if to remind me of my limitations， a tornado(龙卷风) touched down close enough to scatter the jungle gym across an acre of field.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	I assembled the Barbie Townhouse on Christmas Eve. Making it level， keeping the columns from looking like they&#39;d melted and been refrozen， and getting that elevator to work were almost more than I could manage. And building it in curse-free silence so my daughter would continue sleeping--if， in fact， she was sleeping-added a layer of &nbsp;challenge .By dawn I was done .</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Shortly thereafter， my daughter walked into the living room. Her surprise may not be real ， but her delight was utterly genuine and moves me. to this day， 34 years later. Rebecca had spurred &nbsp;me to do something、I didn&#39;t think I could do. It was for her， and一like so much of the privilege of being her farther--it brought me further outside myself and let me overcome doubts about me capacities .</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	37.In the author&rsquo;s eyes , his little daughter was_______</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. obedient &nbsp;B. unstable</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. original &nbsp; D. stubborn</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	38 .The author thought that his daughter&rsquo;s choice of the Barbie Townhouse ,________</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A .was natural for a five-year-old girl</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B．was influenced by her life experience</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C．reflected the change in her taste</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D．brought her back normal</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	39. In the last paragraph the author mainly expressed______</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. his pride in being a father . B. his gratitude to his daughter</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. his concern about his capability &nbsp; &nbsp; D. his delight in helping his daughter</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	42. What can be learned about the relationship between the author and his daughter?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. They are on good terms with each other.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. They keep secrets from each other.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Passage Three</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	It is all very well to blame traffic &nbsp;jam， the cost of petrol and the fast pace of modem life， but manners on the roads are becoming deplorable. Everybody knows that the nicest men become monsters behind the wheel. It is all very well， again ,to have a tiger in the tank， but to have one in the driver&#39;s seat is another matter. You might tolerate the odd road-hog(占道者)， but nowadays the well-mannered motorist is the exception to the rule. Perhaps the situation calls for a &quot;Be Kind to Other Drivers&quot; campaign， otherwise it may get completely out of hand.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Road courtesy is not only good manners， but good sense too, It takes the most good-tempered of drivers to resist the temptation to hit back when subjected to uncivilized behavior. A friendly nod or a wave of acknowledgement in response to an act of courtesy helps to create an atmosphere of goodwill and tolerance so necessary &nbsp;in modem traffic conditions. But such acknowledgements of courtesy are all too rare today. Many drivers nowadays don&#39;t even seem able to recognize courtesy when they see it.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Contrary to general opinion， young drivers have better manners than their seniors. But this is short-lived in the world of modern driving where many drivers neither expect nor give any mercy. This may be encouraged on the battlefield but is out of place on the roads.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Lorry drivers say they have almost abandoned the practice of signaling cars to overtake when the road is clear, because many of the cars took too long to pass. They couldn&#39;t be bothered to select a lower gear. The car drivers, after overtaking, slow eddown again and hogged the road. Again, a motoring magazine has recently drawn attention to the increasing number of drivers who never wait for gaps.&quot;They manufacture them by force， using their direction indicators as a threat rather than a warning.&quot;Punch-ups(打群架)are &nbsp;quite common. It can&#39;t be long before we hear of pistols and knives being used.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Driving is essentially a state of mind. However technically skilled a driver may be，he can&#39;t be an advanced motorist if he is always arrogant and aggressive.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	43. According to the author， a good driver should &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. be technically skilled &nbsp; B. have a good state of mind</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. be sympathetic with others &nbsp;D. take good care of his vehicle</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Passage Four</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	On how the world has changed over the last 50 years，not all of it has been good. As you are looking for organic food information, you have obviously become aware that a better alternative exists and you are taking a critical look at the source and production practices of the companies producing the world&#39;s food supplies.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	The purpose of organic food information is to give you an understanding of what is going into your food. You will see that there are many benefits to organic food that you didn&#39;t know before. The basis behind knowing about organic food information is the fact that farmers are resorting to using artificial fertilizers and pesticides(杀虫剂)to control disease and insect attack in order to produce more crops to satisfy growing demand. These artificial fertilizers leave something poisonous in and on the fruit and vegetables we consume which in turn is absorbed and stored by our bodies.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Even the quality of food has gone down in recent years. Today&#39;s fruits have nowhere near the Vitamin C levels they did at one time. However，with organic food information you learn that organic food has fifty percent more nutrients， minerals and vitamins than any other form of produce that has been grown under intensive farming. If you are eating non-organic produce you will have to eat more fruit in order to make up for this deficiency. But then the dangerous cycle continues since you will be eating more chemicals that are worse for your health than they are good for you.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Another aspect of organic food information is the production of &nbsp;meat and poultry (家禽). Most only consider produce when it comes to organic food information disregarding the antibiotics and hormones that are given to both cattle and poultry that are being force fed. Ask yourself what happens to all these antibiotics and hormones when the animal is killed， the remaining of these antibiotics and growth hormones reside in the meat which are then consumed， digested and stored in human bodies. There is no way that an animal that isn&#39;t kept in healthy conditions can produce healthy food for humans to eat.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	You have nothing to lose by trying organic product，not only will it be healthy for you but you will also be able to eat produce and meat the way they are supposed to be. You will likely be so impressed with the taste of organic fruit that you will never return to the mass-produced fruit again. While cost and availability can be a big issue for some，you can do a bit of research online and find a local store that stocks organic produce for a reasonable price.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	49. It is stated in Paragraph 1 that organic food &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. is considered as a better choice</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. is mostly supplied by world-famous companies</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. has become popular over the last 50 years</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. reflects the change of production practices</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	50. According to Paragraph 3，organic food &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; .</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. has gone down in quality &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;B. has more nutrients</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. can replace mass-produced food &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; D. lacks Vitamin C</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	52. What does the author say about meat and poultry?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. Organic meat and poultry is hardly available.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. In the last paragraph, people are advised to &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. eat traditional produce and meat</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. return to mass-produced fruits</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. do the cost and availability research</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. try organic product for better health and taste</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	54. This passage is mainly about &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. the benefits of organic food information</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. the challenges facing the world food industry</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. changes in food production practices</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. a growing demand high quality food</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Passage Five</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Drinking wastewater? The idea may sound distasteful，but new federally funded research says more Americans are doing so-whether they know or not-and this reuse will be increasingly necessary as the U.S. population expands.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Treated wastewater poses no greater health risks than existing water supplies and， in some cases, may be even safer to drink，according to a report released by the National Research Council. &ldquo;We believe water reuse is an option to deal with growing water scarcity, &nbsp;especially in coastal areas，&rdquo; says Jorg Drewes， an engineering professor at the Colorado School of Mines. &quot;This can be done reliably without putting the public at risk，&quot; he says， citing technological advances. He says it&#39;s a waste not to reuse the nation&#39;s wastewater， because almost all of it is treated before discharge. This water includes storm runoff(径流) as well as used water from homes， businesses and factories.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	In many places，the report says，the public does not realize it&#39;s drinking water that was treated after being discharged as wastewater somewhere upstream: For example， wastewater discharged into the Trinity River from Dallas/Fort Worth flows south into Lake Livingston，the source for Houston&#39;s drinking water.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	Despite the growing importance of this reuse，the report says there&#39;s been no systemic analysis of its extent nationwide since a 1980 study by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Alan Roberson of the American Water Works Association says wastewater reuse is common, so the council&#39;s report is important but not surprising. Roberson expects this recycling will continue to increase，especially for irrigation and industrial needs. He says it will take longer to establish potable(适于饮用的) uses because of public nervousness about drinking wastewater， however treated.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&ldquo;We have to do something to address water scarcity&rdquo;，says Olga Naidenko， a senior scientist at the non-profit Environmental Working Group. &ldquo;Less than 10 of potable water is used for drinking，cooking，showering or dishwashing. We flush it down the toilet，literally.&rdquo; Technologies exist to safely treat the water，she says， although some are expensive.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	The report says water reuse projects tend to cost more， than most water conservation options but less than seawater desalination(脱盐) and other supply alternatives. It calls on the EPA to develop rules that set safe national standards.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	55. As can be learned from Paragraph 1, drinking wastewater &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; .</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. is to become a growing necessity</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. is well received by the Americans</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. has caused heated public debates</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. has become the dominant option</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	56. Which of the following statements would Jorg Drewes agree to?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. Water reuse may eventually put the public at risk.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. Water reuse is preferable to wasting water.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. Water reuse is far from a solution to water shortage.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. Water reuse is possible only after greater tech advances.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	57. Olga Naidenko&rsquo;s remarks emphasize &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. the recent progress &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; B. the existing problems</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. the new perspective &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;D. the potential risks</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	60. What does the report suggest to the EPA?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	A. Weighing different water conservation options.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	B. Exploring new technologies to treat wastewater.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	C. Setting up national standards for water reuse.</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	D. Monitoring water supplies at a national level.</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');

He rejects the idea.<br />\r\nC. He thinks it&#39;s unfair.&nbsp; D. He stands to gain.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n7. Each passage is followed by 6 questions or unfinished statements. For each of them there are 4 choices markedA， B， C and D. Choose the best one and mark the corresponding letter with a single bar across the square brackets on your machine-scoring ANSWER SHEET.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPassage One<br />\r\nA 10-year-old boy decided to study judo(柔道) despite the fact that he had lost his left arm in a terrible car accident. The boy began lessons with an old Japanese judo master， and he was doing well. But he couldn&#39;t understand why， after three months of training，the master had taught him only one move.<br />\r\n&quot;Sir，&quot; the boy finally said， &quot;shouldn&#39;t I be learning more moves?&quot;<br />\r\n&ldquo;This the only move you know， but this is the only move you&#39;ll ever need to know，&quot; the master replied.<br />\r\nNot quite understanding， but believing in his teacher， the boy kept training.<br />\r\nSeveral months later， the master took the boy to his first tournament(锦标赛).<br />\r\nSurprising himself， the boy easily won his first two matches. The third match<br />\r\nproved to be more difficult， but after some time， his opponent became impatient and charged; the boy skillfully used his one move to win the match. Still amazed by his success， the boy was now in the finals.<br />\r\nThis time， his opponent was bigger， stronger， and more experienced. For a while，the boy appeared to be overmatched. Concerned that&nbsp; the boy might get hurt , the&nbsp; referee alled a&nbsp; time-out ,He was about to stop the match when the judomaster intervened.<br />\r\n&quot;No，&quot; the judo master insisted，&quot;Let him continue.&quot;<br />\r\nSoon after the match resumed， his opponent made a critical mistake: he dropped his guard. Instantly， the boy used his move to pin him. The boy had won the match and the tournament. He was the champion.<br />\r\nOn the way home， the boy and his judo master reviewed every move in each and every match. Then the boy summoned the courage to ask what was really on his mind.<br />\r\n&quot;Sir， how did I win the tour&tau;lament with only one move?&quot;<br />\r\n&quot;You won for two. reasons，&quot; the master answered.<br />\r\n&quot;First， you&#39;ve almost mastered one of the most difficult throws in all of judo.<br />\r\nSecond， the only known defense for that move is for your opponent to grab your left arm&rdquo;<br />\r\n<br />\r\n31．Why did the boy want to learn judo?<br />\r\nA. He wanted to get over the accident.<br />\r\nB. He wanted to make up for his disability.<br />\r\nC. He wanted to exercise his right arm.<br />\r\nD&nbsp; .The reason was not mentioned in the passage<br />\r\n<br />\r\n32.When a referee calls a &quot;time-out&rdquo;__________<br />\r\nA. the time has run out<br />\r\nB. the game stops for a short time<br />\r\nC. either side can claim victory<br />\r\nD. the game ends in a tie<br />\r\n<br />\r\n33. Why did the master insist on continuing the match?<br />\r\nA. He didn&#39;t want to give the opponent an advantage.<br />\r\nB. The boy was confident of winning.<br />\r\nC. He had confidence in the boy&#39;s skill.<br />\r\nD. All he cared about was winning the final.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n34.What probably caused the defeat of the boy&#39;s opponent in the final?<br />\r\nA. Over-confidence. B .Impatience.<br />\r\nC.Inexperience.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. Exhaustion.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n35. Why did the master teach the boy only that one move?<br />\r\nA. The boy could not do other moves with only one arm.<br />\r\nB. It was the only move the master knew well.<br />\r\nC. It was the move his opponent would not be good at.<br />\r\nD. His opponent would be helpless once he made that move.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n36. What does the passage mainly tell us？<br />\r\nA. One can turn a weakness into an advantage.<br />\r\nB. It is very difficult to have a good teacher.<br />\r\nC&nbsp;&nbsp; Even a disabled person can win a match.<br />\r\nD.&nbsp; Practice makes perfect.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPassageTwo<br />\r\nMy five-year-old daughter knew exactly what she wanted for Christmas of 1977， and told me so. Yes， she still would like the pink-and-green plastic umbrella， books， long nightgown， slippers-fine. But really， there was only one thing that mattered: a Barbie Townhouse， with all the accessories.<br />\r\nThis was a surprise. Rebecca was not a Barbie girl， preferred stuffed animals to dolls， and wasn&#39;t drawn to play in a structured environment. Always a make-up-the-rules， design-my-own-world， do-it-my-way kid. Maybe， I thought， the point wasn&#39;t Barbie but the house， which she could claim，for herself， since we&rsquo;d&nbsp; already moved five times during her brief life.<br />\r\nNext day， I stopped at the mall. The huge Barbie Townhouse box was there: &quot;3 Floors of High-Styled Fun! Elevator Can Stop on All Floors!&quot; Some Assembly Required.Uh-oh. My track record for assembling things was miserable. Brooklyn-born， I was raised in apartment buildings in a family that didn&#39;t build things. A few years earlier，I &#39;d spent one week assernbling a six-foot-tall jungle gym from a kit containing so many parts. I spent the first four hours sorting and the last two hours trying to figure out why there were so many pieces. The day after I finished building it， as if to remind me of my limitations， a tornado(龙卷风) touched down close enough to scatter the jungle gym across an acre of field.<br />\r\nI assembled the Barbie Townhouse on Christmas Eve. Making it level， keeping the columns from looking like they&#39;d melted and been refrozen， and getting that elevator to work were almost more than I could manage. And building it in curse-free silence so my daughter would continue sleeping--if， in fact， she was sleeping-added a layer of&nbsp; challenge .By dawn I was done .<br />\r\nShortly thereafter， my daughter walked into the living room. Her surprise may not be real ， but her delight was utterly genuine and moves me. to this day， 34 years later. Rebecca had spurred&nbsp; me to do something、I didn&#39;t think I could do. It was for her， and一like so much of the privilege of being her farther--it brought me further outside myself and let me overcome doubts about me capacities .<br />\r\n<br />\r\n37.In the author&rsquo;s eyes , his little daughter was_______<br />\r\nA. obedient&nbsp; B. unstable<br />\r\nC. original&nbsp;&nbsp; D. stubborn<br />\r\n<br />\r\n38 .The author thought that his daughter&rsquo;s choice of the Barbie Townhouse ,________<br />\r\nA .was natural for a five-year-old girl<br />\r\nB．was influenced by her life experience<br />\r\nC．reflected the change in her taste<br />\r\nD．brought her back normal<br />\r\n<br />\r\n39. For the author， assembling things_______&bull;<br />\r\nA. was largely in his blood B. was a challenge he enjoyed<br />\r\nC. was always his weak point&nbsp; D. was part of his family education<br />\r\n<br />\r\n40. Assembling the Barbie Townhouse_________________.<br />\r\nA. brought out the author&#39;s potentials<br />\r\nB. turned out to be easier than expected<br />\r\nC. accually drove the author crazy.<br />\r\nD. was a bad memory for the author<br />\r\n<br />\r\n41. B. his gratitude to his daughter<br />\r\nC. his concern about his capability&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. his delight in helping his daughter<br />\r\n<br />\r\n42. What can be learned about the relationship between the author and his daughter?<br />\r\nA. They are on good terms with each other.<br />\r\nB. They barely speak to each other.<br />\r\nC. They are polite but cold to each other.<br />\r\nD. They keep secrets from each other.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPassage Three<br />\r\nIt is all very well to blame traffic&nbsp; jam， the cost of petrol and the fast pace of modem life， but manners on the roads are becoming deplorable. Everybody knows that the nicest men become monsters behind the wheel. It is all very well， again ,to have a tiger in the tank， but to have one in the driver&#39;s seat is another matter. You might tolerate the odd road-hog(占道者)， but nowadays the well-mannered motorist is the exception to the rule. Perhaps the situation calls for a &quot;Be Kind to Other Drivers&quot; campaign， otherwise it may get completely out of hand.<br />\r\nRoad courtesy is not only good manners， but good sense too, It takes the most good-tempered of drivers to resist the temptation to hit back when subjected to uncivilized behavior. A friendly nod or a wave of acknowledgement in response to an act of courtesy helps to create an atmosphere of goodwill and tolerance so necessary&nbsp; in modem traffic conditions. But such acknowledgements of courtesy are all too rare today. Many drivers nowadays don&#39;t even seem able to recognize courtesy when they see it.<br />\r\nContrary to general opinion， young drivers have better manners than their seniors. But this is short-lived in the world of modern driving where many drivers neither expect nor give any mercy. This may be encouraged on the battlefield but is out of place on the roads.<br />\r\nLorry drivers say they have almost abandoned the practice of signaling cars to overtake when the road is clear, because many of the cars took too long to pass. They couldn&#39;t be bothered to select a lower gear. The car drivers, after overtaking, slow eddown again and hogged the road. Again, a motoring magazine has recently drawn attention to the increasing number of drivers who never wait for gaps.&quot;They manufacture them by force， using their direction indicators as a threat rather than a warning.&quot;Punch-ups(打群架)are&nbsp; quite common. It can&#39;t be long before we hear of pistols and knives being used.<br />\r\nDriving is essentially a state of mind. However technically skilled a driver may be，he can&#39;t be an advanced motorist if he is always arrogant and aggressive.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n43. The author is most concerned about&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. traffic jam B. road manners<br />\r\nC. fast pace of life&nbsp; D. high cost of petrol<br />\r\n<br />\r\n44.&nbsp; The word &quot;deplorable &quot; (Para. 1) most probably means &quot;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &quot;.<br />\r\nA. more serious&nbsp;&nbsp; B. more tempting<br />\r\nC. disturbing&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. noticeable<br />\r\n<br />\r\n45. What is the main idea of Paragraph 2?<br />\r\nA. Many drivers tend to fight back against rude behaviors.<br />\r\nB. A little courtesy may help ease the tensions on the road.<br />\r\nC. Goodwill and tolerance may help relieve traffic jam.<br />\r\nD. Many drivers nowadays lack a good sense of courtesy.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n46. It can be learned from Paragraph 3 that&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. young drivers are more aggressive<br />\r\nB. young drivers would soon lose their good manners<br />\r\nC. elder drivers are more cautious<br />\r\nD. elder drivers should improve their driving skills<br />\r\n<br />\r\n47. An example of good manners on the roads is&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. signaling cars to overtake&nbsp; B. manufacturing a gap<br />\r\nC. selecting a lower gear&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. using the direction indicator<br />\r\n<br />\r\n48. According to the author， a good driver should&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. be technically skilled&nbsp;&nbsp; B. have a good state of mind<br />\r\nC. be sympathetic with others&nbsp; D. take good care of his vehicle<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPassage Four<br />\r\nOn how the world has changed over the last 50 years，not all of it has been good. As you are looking for organic food information, you have obviously become aware that a better alternative exists and you are taking a critical look at the source and production practices of the companies producing the world&#39;s food supplies.<br />\r\nThe purpose of organic food information is to give you an understanding of what is going into your food. You will see that there are many benefits to organic food that you didn&#39;t know before. The basis behind knowing about organic food information is the fact that farmers are resorting to using artificial fertilizers and pesticides(杀虫剂)to control disease and insect attack in order to produce more crops to satisfy growing demand. These artificial fertilizers leave something poisonous in and on the fruit and vegetables we consume which in turn is absorbed and stored by our bodies.<br />\r\nEven the quality of food has gone down in recent years. Today&#39;s fruits have nowhere near the Vitamin C levels they did at one time. However，with organic food information you learn that organic food has fifty percent more nutrients， minerals and vitamins than any other form of produce that has been grown under intensive farming. If you are eating non-organic produce you will have to eat more fruit in order to make up for this deficiency. But then the dangerous cycle continues since you will be eating more chemicals that are worse for your health than they are good for you.<br />\r\nAnother aspect of organic food information is the production of&nbsp; meat and poultry (家禽). Most only consider produce when it comes to organic food information disregarding the antibiotics and hormones that are given to both cattle and poultry that are being force fed. Ask yourself what happens to all these antibiotics and hormones when the animal is killed， the remaining of these antibiotics and growth hormones reside in the meat which are then consumed， digested and stored in human bodies. There is no way that an animal that isn&#39;t kept in healthy conditions can produce healthy food for humans to eat.<br />\r\nYou have nothing to lose by trying organic product，not only will it be healthy for you but you will also be able to eat produce and meat the way they are supposed to be. You will likely be so impressed with the taste of organic fruit that you will never return to the mass-produced fruit again. While cost and availability can be a big issue for some，you can do a bit of research online and find a local store that stocks organic produce for a reasonable price.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n49. It is stated in Paragraph 1 that organic food&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. is considered as a better choice<br />\r\nB. is mostly supplied by world-famous companies<br />\r\nC. has become popular over the last 50 years<br />\r\nD. reflects the change of production practices<br />\r\n<br />\r\n50. Farmers use artificial fertilizers and pesticides to&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. satisfy people&#39;s critical demand&nbsp;&nbsp; B. develop better farming technology<br />\r\nC. get a higher crop yield&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. keep people in better health<br />\r\n<br />\r\n51. According to Paragraph 3，organic food&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. has gone down in quality&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. has more nutrients<br />\r\nC. can replace mass-produced food&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. lacks Vitamin C<br />\r\n<br />\r\n52. What does the author say about meat and poultry?<br />\r\nA. Organic meat and poultry is hardly available.<br />\r\nB. A great amount of meat is consumed every year.<br />\r\nC. Merciless killing of the animals lowers their quality.<br />\r\nD. They may contain antibiotics and growth hormones.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n53. In the last paragraph, people are advised to&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. eat traditional produce and meat<br />\r\nB. return to mass-produced fruits<br />\r\nC. do the cost and availability research<br />\r\nD. try organic product for better health and taste<br />\r\n<br />\r\n54. This passage is mainly about&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. the benefits of organic food information<br />\r\nB. the challenges facing the world food industry<br />\r\nC. changes in food production practices<br />\r\nD. a growing demand high quality food<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPassage Five<br />\r\n<br />\r\nDrinking wastewater? The idea may sound distasteful，but new federally funded research says more Americans are doing so-whether they know or not-and this reuse will be increasingly necessary as the U.S. population expands.<br />\r\nTreated wastewater poses no greater health risks than existing water supplies and， in some cases, may be even safer to drink，according to a report released by the National Research Council. &ldquo;We believe water reuse is an option to deal with growing water scarcity,&nbsp; especially in coastal areas，&rdquo; says Jorg Drewes， an engineering professor at the Colorado School of Mines. &quot;This can be done reliably without putting the public at risk，&quot; he says， citing technological advances. He says it&#39;s a waste not to reuse the nation&#39;s wastewater， because almost all of it is treated before discharge. This water includes storm runoff(径流) as well as used water from homes， businesses and factories.<br />\r\nIn many places，the report says，the public does not realize it&#39;s drinking water that was treated after being discharged as wastewater somewhere upstream: For example， wastewater discharged into the Trinity River from Dallas/Fort Worth flows south into Lake Livingston，the source for Houston&#39;s drinking water.<br />\r\nDespite the growing importance of this reuse，the report says there&#39;s been no systemic analysis of its extent nationwide since a 1980 study by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Alan Roberson of the American Water Works Association says wastewater reuse is common, so the council&#39;s report is important but not surprising. Roberson expects this recycling will continue to increase，especially for irrigation and industrial needs. He says it will take longer to establish potable(适于饮用的) uses because of public nervousness about drinking wastewater， however treated.<br />\r\n&ldquo;We have to do something to address water scarcity&rdquo;，says Olga Naidenko， a senior scientist at the non-profit Environmental Working Group. &ldquo;Less than 10 of potable water is used for drinking，cooking，showering or dishwashing. We flush it down the toilet，literally.&rdquo; Technologies exist to safely treat the water，she says， although some are expensive.<br />\r\nThe report says water reuse projects tend to cost more， than most water conservation options but less than seawater desalination(脱盐) and other supply alternatives. It calls on the EPA to develop rules that set safe national standards.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n55. As can be learned from Paragraph 1, drinking wastewater&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. is to become a growing necessity<br />\r\nB. is well received by the Americans<br />\r\nC. has caused heated public debates<br />\r\nD. has become the dominant option<br />\r\n<br />\r\n56. Which of the following statements would Jorg Drewes agree to?<br />\r\nA. Water reuse may eventually put the public at risk.<br />\r\nB. Water reuse is preferable to wasting water.<br />\r\nC. Water reuse is far from a solution to water shortage.<br />\r\nD. Water reuse is possible only after greater tech advances.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n57. Lake Livingston is mentioned to show that the public&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. accepts the fact of drinking wastewater calmly<br />\r\nB. is concerned about the safety of the drinking water<br />\r\nC. does not believe that wastewater is safe to drink.<br />\r\nD. is not aware of the nature of their drinking water<br />\r\n<br />\r\n58. According to Alan Roberson,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. it is not safe to drink wastewater<br />\r\nB. the report has surprised the public<br />\r\nC. the report helps build up public confidence<br />\r\nD. the public has yet to accept drinking wasterwater<br />\r\n<br />\r\n59. Olga Naidenko&rsquo;s remarks emphasize&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; .<br />\r\nA. the recent progress&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; B. the existing problems<br />\r\nC. the new perspective&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; D. the potential risks<br />\r\n<br />\r\n60. What does the report suggest to the EPA?<br />\r\nA. Weighing different water conservation options.<br />\r\nB. Exploring new technologies to treat wastewater.<br />\r\nC. Setting up national standards for water reuse.<br />\r\nD. Monitoring water supplies at a national level.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPart IVCloze (15 minutes， 15 points， 1 for each)<br />\r\n<br />\r\nDirections: In this part， there is a passage with J 5 blanks. Write your translation on the ANSWER SHEET.<br />\r\nIn many ways the Internet has had a very positive effect on society.It has improved communication ,simplified handling tasks,offered a huge convenience,enabled faster processing ,and provided more options,all of which frees more time to do other things .Yet,interestingly enough ,the Internet has in some ways had negative effects.The quality of communication has declined and people are impatient because they have become accustomed to instant satisfaction,and using the Internet also takes up a lot of time.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nSection B<br />\r\nDirections: Translate the following passage into English. But he couldn&#39;t understand why， after three months of training，the master had taught him only one move.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&quot;Sir，&quot; the boy finally said， &quot;shouldn&#39;t I be learning more moves?&quot;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&ldquo;This the only move you know， but this is the only move you&#39;ll ever need to&nbsp;know，&quot; the master replied.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Not quite understanding， but believing in his teacher， the boy kept training.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Several months later， the master took the boy to his first tournament(锦标赛).</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Surprising himself， the boy easily won his first two matches. But really， there was only one thing that mattered: a Barbie Townhouse， with all the accessories.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		This was a surprise. Rebecca was not a Barbie girl， preferred stuffed animals to dolls， and wasn&#39;t drawn to play in a structured environment. Always a make-up-the-rules， design-my-own-world， do-it-my-way kid. Maybe， I thought， the point wasn&#39;t Barbie but the house， which she could claim，for herself， since we&rsquo;d &nbsp;already moved five times during her brief life.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Next day， I stopped at the mall. The huge Barbie Townhouse box was there: &quot;3 Floors of High-Styled Fun! Elevator Can Stop on All Floors!&quot; Some Assembly Required.Uh-oh. My track record for assembling things was miserable. Brooklyn-born， I was raised in apartment buildings in a family that didn&#39;t build things. A few years earlier，I &#39;d spent one week assernbling a six-foot-tall jungle gym from a kit containing so many parts. I spent the first four hours sorting and the last two hours trying to figure out why there were so many pieces. The day after I finished building it， as if to remind me of my limitations， a tornado(龙卷风) touched down close enough to scatter the jungle gym across an acre of field.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		I assembled the Barbie Townhouse on Christmas Eve. Making it level， keeping the columns from looking like they&#39;d melted and been refrozen， and getting that elevator to work were almost more than I could manage. And building it in curse-free silence so my daughter would continue sleeping--if， in fact， she was sleeping-added a layer of &nbsp;challenge .By dawn I was done .</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Shortly thereafter， my daughter walked into the living room. Her surprise may not be real ， but her delight was utterly genuine and moves me. to this day， 34 years later. Rebecca had spurred &nbsp;me to do something、I didn&#39;t think I could do. It was for her， and一like so much of the privilege of being her farther--it brought me further outside myself and let me overcome doubts about me capacities .</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		37.In the author&rsquo;s eyes , his little daughter was_______</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. obedient &nbsp;B. unstable</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. original &nbsp; D. stubborn</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		38 .The author thought that his daughter&rsquo;s choice of the Barbie Townhouse ,________</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A .was natural for a five-year-old girl</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B．was influenced by her life experience</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C．reflected the change in her taste</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D．brought her back normal</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		39. B. his gratitude to his daughter</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. his concern about his capability &nbsp; &nbsp; D. his delight in helping his daughter</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		42. What can be learned about the relationship between the author and his daughter?</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. They are on good terms with each other.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. They barely speak to each other.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. They are polite but cold to each other.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. They keep secrets from each other.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		<strong>Passage Three</strong></div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		It is all very well to blame traffic &nbsp;jam， the cost of petrol and the fast pace of&nbsp;modem life， but manners on the roads are becoming deplorable. Everybody knows that the nicest men become monsters behind the wheel. It is all very well， again ,to have a tiger in the tank， but to have one in the driver&#39;s seat is another matter. You might tolerate the odd road-hog(占道者)， but nowadays the well-mannered motorist is the exception to the rule. Perhaps the situation calls for a &quot;Be Kind to Other Drivers&quot; campaign， otherwise it may get completely out of hand.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Road courtesy is not only good manners， but good sense too, It takes the most&nbsp;good-tempered of drivers to resist the temptation to hit back when subjected to&nbsp;uncivilized behavior. A friendly nod or a wave of acknowledgement in response to an&nbsp;act of courtesy helps to create an atmosphere of goodwill and tolerance so necessary &nbsp;in modem traffic conditions. But such acknowledgements of courtesy are all too rare today. Many drivers nowadays don&#39;t even seem able to recognize courtesy when they see it.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Contrary to general opinion， young drivers have better manners than their seniors. But this is short-lived in the world of modern driving where many drivers neither expect nor give any mercy. This may be encouraged on the battlefield but is out of place on the roads.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Lorry drivers say they have almost abandoned the practice of signaling cars to&nbsp;overtake when the road is clear, because many of the cars took too long to pass. They&nbsp;couldn&#39;t be bothered to select a lower gear. The car drivers, after overtaking, slow eddown again and hogged the road. Again, a motoring magazine has recently drawn attention to the increasing number of drivers who never wait for gaps.&quot;They&nbsp;manufacture them by force， using their direction indicators as a threat rather than a&nbsp;warning.&quot;Punch-ups(打群架)are &nbsp;quite common. It can&#39;t be long before we hear of&nbsp;pistols and knives being used.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Driving is essentially a state of mind. However technically skilled a driver may be，he can&#39;t be an advanced motorist if he is always arrogant and aggressive.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		43. The author is most concerned about &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. traffic jam B. road manners</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. fast pace of life &nbsp;D. high cost of petrol</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		44. &nbsp;The word &quot;deplorable &quot; (Para. 1) most probably means &quot; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &quot;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. more serious &nbsp; B. more tempting</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. disturbing &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;D. noticeable</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		45. According to the author， a good driver should &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. be technically skilled &nbsp; B. have a good state of mind</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. be sympathetic with others &nbsp;D. take good care of his vehicle</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		<strong>Passage Four</strong></div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		On how the world has changed over the last 50 years，not all of it has been good. As you are looking for organic food information, you have obviously become aware that a better alternative exists and you are taking a critical look at the source and production practices of the companies producing the world&#39;s food supplies.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		The purpose of organic food information is to give you an understanding of what is going into your food. You will see that there are many benefits to organic food that you didn&#39;t know before. The basis behind knowing about organic food information is the fact that farmers are resorting to using artificial fertilizers and pesticides(杀虫剂)to control disease and insect attack in order to produce more crops to satisfy growing demand. These artificial fertilizers leave something poisonous in and on the fruit and vegetables we consume which in turn is absorbed and stored by our bodies.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Even the quality of food has gone down in recent years. Today&#39;s fruits have nowhere near the Vitamin C levels they did at one time. However，with organic food information you learn that organic food has fifty percent more nutrients， minerals and vitamins than any other form of produce that has been grown under intensive farming. If you are eating non-organic produce you will have to eat more fruit in order to make up for this deficiency. But then the dangerous cycle continues since you will be eating more chemicals that are worse for your health than they are good for you.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Another aspect of organic food information is the production of &nbsp;meat and poultry (家禽). Most only consider produce when it comes to organic food information disregarding the antibiotics and hormones that are given to both cattle and poultry that are being force fed. Ask yourself what happens to all these antibiotics and hormones when the animal is killed， the remaining of these antibiotics and growth hormones reside in the meat which are then consumed， digested and stored in human bodies. There is no way that an animal that isn&#39;t kept in healthy conditions can produce healthy food for humans to eat.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		You have nothing to lose by trying organic product，not only will it be healthy for you but you will also be able to eat produce and meat the way they are supposed to be. You will likely be so impressed with the taste of organic fruit that you will never return to the mass-produced fruit again. While cost and availability can be a big issue for some，you can do a bit of research online and find a local store that stocks organic produce for a reasonable price.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		49. It is stated in Paragraph 1 that organic food &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. is considered as a better choice</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. is mostly supplied by world-famous companies</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. has become popular over the last 50 years</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. reflects the change of production practices</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		50. This passage is mainly about &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. the benefits of organic food information</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. the challenges facing the world food industry</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. changes in food production practices</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. a growing demand high quality food</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		<strong>Passage Five</strong></div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Drinking wastewater? The idea may sound distasteful，but new federally funded research says more Americans are doing so-whether they know or not-and this reuse will be increasingly necessary as the U.S. population expands.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Treated wastewater poses no greater health risks than existing water supplies and， in some cases, may be even safer to drink，according to a report released by the National Research Council. &ldquo;We believe water reuse is an option to deal with growing water scarcity, &nbsp;especially in coastal areas，&rdquo; says Jorg Drewes， an engineering professor at the Colorado School of Mines. &quot;This can be done reliably without putting the public at risk，&quot; he says， citing technological advances. He says it&#39;s a waste not to reuse the nation&#39;s wastewater， because almost all of it is treated before discharge. This water includes storm runoff(径流) as well as used water from homes， businesses and factories.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		In many places，the report says，the public does not realize it&#39;s drinking water that was treated after being discharged as wastewater somewhere upstream: For example， wastewater discharged into the Trinity River from Dallas/Fort Worth flows south into Lake Livingston，the source for Houston&#39;s drinking water.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Despite the growing importance of this reuse，the report says there&#39;s been no systemic analysis of its extent nationwide since a 1980 study by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Alan Roberson of the American Water Works Association says wastewater reuse is common, so the council&#39;s report is important but not surprising. Roberson expects this recycling will continue to increase，especially for irrigation and industrial needs. He says it will take longer to establish potable(适于饮用的) uses because of public nervousness about drinking wastewater， however treated.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&ldquo;We have to do something to address water scarcity&rdquo;，says Olga Naidenko， a senior scientist at the non-profit Environmental Working Group. &ldquo;Less than 10 of potable water is used for drinking，cooking，showering or dishwashing. We flush it down the toilet，literally.&rdquo; Technologies exist to safely treat the water，she says， although some are expensive.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		The report says water reuse projects tend to cost more， than most water conservation options but less than seawater desalination(脱盐) and other supply alternatives. It calls on the EPA to develop rules that set safe national standards.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		55. As can be learned from Paragraph 1, drinking wastewater &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; .</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. is to become a growing necessity</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. is well received by the Americans</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. has caused heated public debates</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. has become the dominant option</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		56. Olga Naidenko&rsquo;s remarks emphasize &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. the recent progress &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; B. the existing problems</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. the new perspective &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;D. the potential risks</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		60. What does the report suggest to the EPA?</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. Weighing different water conservation options.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. Exploring new technologies to treat wastewater.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. Setting up national standards for water reuse.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. Monitoring water supplies at a national level.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		<strong>Part IVCloze (15 minutes， 15 points， 1 for each)</strong></div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Directions: In this part， there is a passage with J 5 blanks. For each blank there are 4 choices marked A， B， C， and D. Choose the best answer for each blank and mark the corresponding letter with a single bar across the square brackets on your machine-scoring ANSWER SHEET.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Why do kids hate Brussels sprouts(芽甘苦)? Because Brussels sprouts are bitter， and kids generally don&#39;t like bitter tastes. But it&#39;s not their &nbsp;61 . Researchers say that a dislike for bitter and sour is a survival instinct，since most toxic substances &nbsp;62 &nbsp;that way too. On the other hand， sweetness typically indicates that something is 63 &nbsp;to eat， so children are born with a 64 &nbsp;for sweets.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		What we like to eat changes over time. As we age， we realize that 65 somethingtastes bitter or sour， it won&#39;t kill us，and we learn to 66 it. When we&#39;re older， we 67 &nbsp;some of our smell sensitivity .Humans need smell to experience flavor,which isdifferent from taste. With our semes diminished， we&#39;ll probably begin 68 sugar and salt to our food， to heighten the flavor. 69 ， there&#39;s a theory that the reason many especially &quot;big&quot; &ndash;tasting &nbsp;wines in recent years have won awards is that wine critics are getting older and finding subtle flavors 70 to sense.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		If someone is71 to detect flavors at all， he may have a taste72， which can becaused by a tongue injury or &nbsp;brain damage. Or it could be a problem with73 .The&nbsp;channel that separates the mouth from the nose allows us to smell behind our nose and is 74 enjoying most complex flavors.That&#39;s why food seems 75 when we have a&nbsp;stuffy nose-except chicken noodle soup.It&#39;s so salty.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		61. A. fault &nbsp;B. choice C. habit &nbsp;D. regret</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		62. A. feel &nbsp;B. look C. sound D. taste</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		63. Write your translation on the ANSWER SHEET.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		In many ways the Internet has had a very positive effect on society.It has improved communication ,simplified handling tasks,offered a huge convenience,enabled faster processing ,and provided more options,all of which frees more time to do other things .Yet,interestingly enough ,the Internet has in some ways had negative effects.The quality of communication has declined and people are impatient because they have become accustomed to instant satisfaction,and using the Internet also takes up a lot of time.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Section B</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Directions: Translate the following passage into English. Write your translation on the ANSWER SHEET.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		乔布斯（Steve Jobs）去世后备受敬仰，原因之一是他创造了科技产品的美感。乔布斯认为无论汽车还是电脑，人们都愿意购买一些比同类产品更为美观的东西。在乔布斯的领导下，从产品外形、材料到使用感受等各个方面，苹果都带来了无与伦比的体验，让人们的生活变得更加美丽。</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		<strong>PartⅡ Writing (30 minutes ,15 points)</strong></div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Directions :In this part ,you are to write within 30 minutes a composition of less than 150 words under the title of &ldquo;my Favorite Way of keeping Fit &rdquo;Some clues are given below in Chinese . INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5634','143','<div>\r\n	　　同等学力和同等学历有很大的区别，这与我国目前的学历教育和非学历教育有关。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　同等学力指学习经历不同，但在知识水平和学力能力方面达到同等程度的人员。在学位与研究生教育工作中经常出现和使用的概念。通常指申请学位者或报考研究生的考生中，虽然没有大学本科或者硕士生、博士生学历（包括获得相应的学位），但通过自学或其它途径达到了相当于大学本科或硕士生以及博士生申请论文答辩时的知识和能力水平的人员。同等学力是非本科、硕士生毕业者报考硕士生、博士生，以及不具备硕士生、博士生学历的人员申请硕士和博士学位时的必要条件。在我国，同等学力资格须经申请人所在单位证明以及接受其报考或申请的单位审核。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　同等学历指具有与某级教育相同层次的学历或者获得同级教育但非同一学科、专业的毕业证书（包括相应的学位）。同等学历的概念在学位与研究生教育工作中有参考意义。如在研究生招生工作中经常出现的同等学历考生（非某一学科专业毕业的本科、硕士生或学士、硕士学位获得者）跨学科、专业报考硕士生、博士生；在学位工作中出现的非本学科、专业毕业的同等学历申请者（硕士、博士研究生或硕士、博士学位获得者）跨学科、专业申请硕士、博士学位等。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5635','144','　　2012年同等学力申硕考试成绩已经公布，2013年同等学力申硕考试备战已经打响，那么考生应该如何备战呢？<strong><a href=\"http://www.ruconline.com\">人大在职研</a></strong>老师认为应该按照以下时间段进行合理的安排英语复习：<br />\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　第一阶段，基础巩固阶段&mdash;&mdash;7月份至11月底</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　从现在到11月底，考生需要重点复习词汇和语法，主要掌握考试大纲要求的重点的需要理解运用的词汇；注意形近词的辨析；主要掌握考试大纲中要求的2360个积极词汇，理解并能灵活的运用；语法部分主要掌握基本语法知识，常用的句型和结构，比如定语从句、名词性从句、状语从句，掌握英语的时态和主动、被动语态；较难的固定结构的语法，比如as的用法；It的用法等等；复习时要注意学练结合，不能只是背，不会运用；</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　对于英语基础较差的考生或者是零基础的考生，为了便于后期的备考，一定要通过这个阶段把基础打好，而且同等学力的考试相当于大学英语六级的水平，考生一定不能轻视；要早备考，早复习。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　第二阶段，强化复习阶段&mdash;&mdash;12月&mdash;明年2月</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　从12月到2月中旬，这个阶段考生一定要针对历年真题为主进行认真学习，并且相对应的做一些练习题；在词汇方面，重点记忆历年真题中出现的自己不认识的词汇；将语法知识全部弄懂，注意较难的语法部分，比如虚拟语气，倒装句，插入语；这个阶段复习时，阅读需要精读，将文章中的每一个单词、长难句都弄懂，注意自己要将阅读长难的句子结合语境翻译一遍，至少保证每天做两篇至三篇阅读；注意做题的质量，后期阶段再注意做题的速度；做翻译真题时，一定要落实在纸面上，注意措辞、用句；注意与原文保持一致，并且通顺。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　第三阶段，冲刺复习阶段&mdash;&mdash;明年3月&mdash;考前</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　在3月到5月底，考生要进行最后一轮的全面复习，将真题、练习题中做错的题目再温习一遍；重点对翻译、作文进行强化训练；针对各个题型，再次运用学到的知识的技巧，按照考试时间整体性的进行测试，最后进行查漏补缺；这阶段要注意积累写作的素材，因为我们英语考试的作文出题范围比较广泛，所以注意每一类型的作文题目至少练习两篇，最后一个月背一背作文模板，确保顺利通过考试。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　2013年同等学力考试改革，难度有降但考生不可掉以轻心，提前备考确保通关</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　2013年同等学力的英语考试大纲已经改革，删除了一卷和二卷的设置，删除了二卷18分的限制，这对大部分考生来说是个好消息，但是我们也不能掉以轻心，一定要做到全面复习，提前备考。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');

INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5639','144','<div>\r\n	　　虽然目前2013年<a href=\"http://www.ruconline.com\">同等学力</a>英语考试大纲短时间内不能出版发布，我们也不能得知如何出题，会有什么样类型的题目，但是英语的考试万变不离其中，基本上2013年的考题类型也不会有太大的变化，基本上也会涵盖词汇、阅读、完型、翻译、写作等这几种类型；那我们该怎么做来应对2013年的同等学力英语考试呢？</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　1、 词汇必背。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　根据第五版考试大纲的词汇表认真背一遍考试要求的词汇，强化记忆高频及重点词汇，在词汇记忆时要注意词汇的同义词、反义词、加入前缀后缀的派生词等。注意词汇记忆方法，记忆词汇时，要掌握一些词汇的固定搭配及用法。不能只记读音和含义。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　2、 历年真题必研究。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　这里说的真题主要是从2000年--2012年的英语真题，因为考试大纲版本的变化，08年以前和第五版考纲不一致的题型都可以暂时不做，待第六版考纲公布后，再决定是否需要做，比如改错题等。要将真题中的每个题，每篇文章都理解透彻。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　3、 备考必做复习计划，认真复习，重视方法。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　将整个备考复习分阶段进行，2013年年底之前，做题是都要先重视质量，之后再逐步提高做题速度。复习每个部分时，都要注意方法，以便取得事半功倍的效果。不要盲目做题。另外，备考要循序渐进，不要着急，更不能在临近考试时，依靠押题通过。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　4、 选择网络课程备考，更能满足广大在职考生</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　考生们大多为英语基础较差，或是有一定基础但多年未接触英语，导致英语水平大大缩水。建议广大考生一定要提前做好备考准备，选择适合自己的辅导班，踏踏实实从基础学，为一次通关打下基础。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　对于广大在职考生来说，培训机构的网络辅导班更为适合，学习时间地点不受限制，还能反复听课，且现在报名就可学习，不管在家还是在办公室，还是在外出差，都可以让英语备考随时随地。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　5、 坚持到底，沉着应对。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　我们在职的很多考生常常会因为各种原因，而未能参加本次考试，对我们在职的考生来说，一年只有一次的机会就这样被浪费掉了，所以我们建议大家不管遇到什么困难，一定要相信自己，坚持到最后。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5640','145','　　<a href=\"http://www.ruconline.com\">在职研究生</a>按照考试时间、考试形式、颁发证书等的不同，其考试竞争激烈程度也是不一样的。<br />\r\n　　一般而言，参加每年1月份的全国硕士研究生统一入学考试，获得国家认可的&ldquo;双证书&rdquo;(学历证书和硕士学位证书)，这是我们最为熟知的也是竞争最激烈的获得硕士学位的方式。','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5641','145','<div>\r\n	　　与1月统考和十月联考相比，同等学力申请硕士学位，这是国家在现行的硕士学位教育渠道之外开辟的一条使具有研究生毕业同等学力人员获得学位的渠道。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　一般来说，同等学力申请硕士学位须具备以下条件：(1)获学士学位后具有3年以上工作经验；(2)通过学位授予单位的资格审查；(3)通过学位授予单位组织的课程考试；(4)通过在每年的5月进行的同等学力人员申请硕士学位的外国语水平及学科综合水平全国统一考试；(5)在通过全部考试后的一年内完成学位论文，并通过论文答辩。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　从表面上看，该方式是&ldquo;免试入学，边学边考&rdquo;，应该很容易获取学位，其实并非如此。按照规定，申请人自通过资格审查之日起，如果未在4年内通过学位授予单位的全部课程考试和国家组织的水平考试，则本次申请无效。由于不少学校奉行&ldquo;宽进严出&rdquo;的政策，因此这种方式获得学位并不容易，有些专业的通过率甚至不到10%。此外，不少学校还要求学生在读期间必须公开发表一定篇数的学术论文，这无形中也给顺利毕业增加了一定的难度。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5642','145','<div>\r\n	　　国务院学位办日前下发通知，放宽以研究生毕业同等学力申请硕士学位相关课程考试及国家统考的年限限制，进一步明确申硕人员的资格范围。自2012年起同等学力申硕不再统一学习年限，由各院校自行决定。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　据了解，国务院学位委员会1998年制定的《关于授予具有研究生毕业同等学力人员硕士、博士学位的规定》，规定了以研究生毕业同等学力申请硕士、博士学位的条件和具体程序。其中包括研究生毕业同等学力人员申请硕士学位须&ldquo;已获得学士学位，并在获得学士学位后工作三年以上&rdquo;;申请人员学习研究生课程方式不限，但&ldquo;自通过资格审查之日起，必须在四年内完成学位授予单位组织的全部课程考试和国家组织的水平考试，且成绩合格。四年内未通过，本次申请无效&rdquo;。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　此次政策调整主要涉及上述年限规定。即申请学位人员通过上述考试的期限不再由国家统一规定，而由学位授予单位自行规定。这一调整更加适应大部分人在职学习提高的特点和终身学习理念的要求，减少在职人员学业和工作相互影响的矛盾，为申请学位人员提供了更加合理、宽松的学习空间。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　此次政策调整扩大了申请人的范围。在原来&ldquo;已获得学士学位，并在获得学士学位后工作三年以上&rdquo;的基础上，增加了&ldquo;虽无学士学位但已获得硕士或博士学位&rdquo;者。同时规定，前置学位是国(境)外学位的，其学位须经教育部留学服务中心认证。因此，此项调整为更多的有深造需求的人员提供了机会。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　我国目前经批准开展此项工作的硕士学位授予单位为453个，每年约有3万人通过此渠道获得硕士学位，约占硕士学位获得者总数的7.5%。国务院学位委员会办公室已委托教育部学位与研究生教育发展中心开发建设&ldquo;全国同等学力人员申请硕士学位管理信息平台&rdquo;，为有关部门和学位授予单位提供统一、高效的信息管理平台，为社会公众提供及时、权威的信息，也为同等学力申请硕士学位人员提供集高校信息查询、学位申请注册、课程考试备案、统考报名、成绩查询等一系列信息服务。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5643','144','<div>\r\n	<br />\r\n	　　同等学力申硕英语考试复习有很多的方法，<a href=\"http://www.ruconline.com\">人大在职研</a>老师认为以下12种方法是最有效的。<br />\r\n	　　<strong>方法一：单词会也得会，不会也得会。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　同等学力申硕英语考试大纲的词是完全可以通过上下文猜到的。备考时即使不会你完全可以在考试时弄懂。猜的技巧就是，上下文中肯定有和超纲词所在句子相关的句子，肯定可以找出和超纲词词性相近的词汇，再对比下两句的结构，就会发现，要么一句是另一句的同义替换，要么就是一句是另一句的深度解释。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　方法二：对于慢热型选手，要自己先预热</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　你对新事物的理解比其他人要慢一些，或者说你需要花费一段时间去揣摩下才能发现解决问题的诀窍的话，那么无论在你正式进入同等学力申硕英语考试前，还是平时模拟测验前，都要先预热一下，对你做题非常有帮助的。就像太极拳的打法，由慢至快，由柔至刚，直至达到速度飘忽不定，刚柔相并，才是最高境界。<br />\r\n	&nbsp;</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<strong>　　方法第三：英语、数学天天不要落</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　同时考在职研究生数学和英语的人，在最后的两个月里，数学和英语每天都要进行，比如今天复习了数学就要复习些英语，今天看了些英语就也要再做点数学题。直到同等学力申硕英语考试的前一天也是如此。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法四：训练阅读，点到即可。</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　在职研究生英语阅读能力的提高是很漫长的事情。可考试不等人，到了后期，如果你打好了一定的基础的话，练习阅读，就不要再看课外的英语读物了。不是说它不好，而是说它不是最佳方式。以历年的同等学力申硕英语考试真题为主，勤学苦练，才是最终攻克在职研究生英语阅读的不二法门。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法五：要算分</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　在职研究生英语考试多数都是选择题，如果你基础不好想凭上考场那一时的运气，那你说胜算是多少呢?</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法六：要专项突破</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　翻译和新题型其实提高起来比较快，这段时间就是要好好突击下这两块的题目。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法七：重视写作得分</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　在真题演练的过程中，在职研究生考生要善于发现语言亮点，总结出一套适合自己的写作模板，这样既可以提高自己写作水平，又避免了与其他模板雷同，造成千篇一律，真正拿到写作高分。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法八：数学复习要保持充足的睡眠</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　在职研究生数学是智慧的游戏，据我所知许多数学家、数学高手都是很会睡觉很会休息的人，好的休息才能保证大脑有好的状态，才能玩得好数学，也就是说不能打&ldquo;疲劳战&rdquo;，会休息的人才会学习。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法九、错题集是你的好老师</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　据经验，很多考生在真正的同等学力申硕英语考试的时候都会犯自己以前犯过的错误，原因就是遗忘。类似于英语背单词一样，对于容易忘记的解题方法，实在想不出来就记下来，时不时地去翻看。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法十：限定时间做题</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　无论哪一科，在考前，都要把时间换算好。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法十一：巧背政治</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　政治要分开科目去对待，哲学和政经基本是不需要怎么背的，其余都是要背的。如果对分数要求较高的话，应该多做题，从题目中就可以找到考点，精背常考点的知识点。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　<br />\r\n	<strong>　　方法十二：工欲善其事，必先利其器</strong></div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　写字答题的笔，还是很有讲究的。要选对颜色。最后需要注意，我们选择签字笔时，要选择细笔头的，最好用0.35的，而不要用0.5的。0.5的有点粗，我们的英语答题卡大小类似于A4纸的一半大，所以要用细笔头的笔写才够地方。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');
INSERT INTO `addonarticle` VALUES('5644','143','　　在职研究生有学历和学力之分，<a href=\"http://www.ruconline.com\">人大在职研究生</a>进修班的学生在通过同等学力申硕成功的学生，可以颁发硕士学位。<br />\r\n　　尽管具备了更实用、方便的特点，但是很多人在选择继续教育时，仍然对同等学力申硕存有疑虑。其中一部分即来自于对学历的曲解。\r\n<div>\r\n	　　所谓学历，是对于某个学生于一定时间里在学校受过教育的认可，并不能证明其学术理论水平和研究水平，也不能代表他的学习能力。而学位则是对某人学术研究能力的认可。对于大学以下教育，学历的存在是有一定意义的，但是对于更高层次的、注重学术研究能力的硕士教育来说，学位本身比学历更有说服力。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　人们观念中仍然存在的误解，认为只拿学位证书不如双证有含金量、有保障，对于同等学力申硕考试的发展形成了一定的障碍，也使得每年1月份的硕士研究生考试成了千军万马过独木桥。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　但从国外教育发展的趋势来看，越来越多用人单位、考生个人都必然对代表个人能力水平的学位证书越来越重视，淡化学历证书所扮演的角色。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　很多人都不太清楚，研究生进修班到底是一个什么样的概念，它和同等学力申硕到底是什么样的关系。对此，我们可以理解为，研究生进修班是参加同等学力硕士研究生考试、获得同等学力硕士学位的主要桥梁，由各单位根据自己专业设置情况来提供。</div>\r\n<div>\r\n	　　同等学力申硕的前提是具备同等的学术和能力，而仅建立在实践基础上的自学、总结，很容易造成课程学习不系统和出现盲点，理论基础也相对薄弱。参加统一考试通过率也不高。正是出于这样的考虑，学校举办了研究生进修班，为学员提供知识的梳理，介绍前沿最新的研究成果，针对考点进行有针对性的辅导，使之达到要求的学术技术水平。</div>\r\n','','','59.108.73.73');

What a pity! &nbsp; &nbsp; B. How annoying!</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. I&#39;m sorry to hear that . D. So far so good.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		3.Speaker A:When Lisa saw me at the mall， she didn&#39;t even say hello to me.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Speaker B: I can&#39; t understand why______. I thought you were good &nbsp;friends.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. you greeted her first &nbsp;B. she was also there at the time</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. she gave you the cold shoulder</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. you should have cared<br />\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		4. Speaker A: I used to make delicious pies， but this one tastes terrible.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Speaker B: I think you&#39;re really</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. out of date B. out of touch</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. out of hand</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. out of practice</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		5.Speaker A: Dr. Smith, what&#39;s wrong with my father?</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		Speaker B: Well,______ &nbsp;considering his advanced age.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		A. he&#39;s in pretty good shape &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;B. don&#39;t ask me such a question</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. At the end of each conversation there is a question followed by 4 choices marked A， B， C， and D. Choose the best answer to the question from the 4 choices by marking the corresponding letter with a single bar across the square brackets on your machine-scoring ANSWER SHEET.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		6. He agrees to the proposal. B. He rejects the idea.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. He thinks it&#39;s unfair. &nbsp;D. He stands to gain.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		7. There are already too many people.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. He can&#39;t promise the woman now.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. The woman is welcome to join them.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D. It&#39;s a real bargain.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. It&#39;s not worth the price. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;D: It&#39;s unexpected.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		&nbsp;</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		9. He would scratch the paint off its surface.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		B. He would tear it down first.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		C. He would make some repairs.</div>\r\n	<div>\r\n		D.
